I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FACILITY 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The  transaction  technical  assistance  facility  (TRTA  facility)  will  provide  financial 
management, procurement, and project management-related capacity building and support to 
ongoing and future projects within South Asia. Lessons learned from the implementation of TA 
8555-REG have contributed to the improvement of effective procurement operations and project 
implementation  in  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  funded  projects  in  South  Asia. 1 
Notwithstanding  the  successful  implementation  of  the  previous  TA,  the  continuation  and 
expansion of the scope of the TRTA facility support is essential for the growth of ADB operations 
in the region in response to the new operational demands under Strategy 2030. The proposed 
support  would  include  country  and  sector  specific  assessments  and  recommendations  on 
financial and project management, and procurement processes. Specifically, the TRTA facility will 
provide (i) demand driven assistance on project design and implementation; (ii) studies, seminars 
and workshops on financial management; (iii) enhancement of the procurement and contract 
management  capacity  of  executing  agencies  through  the  engagement  of  IT  specialists, 
procurement consultants and International Federation of Consulting Engineers (FIDIC) experts; 
and (iv) knowledge sharing of best practices. 
 
2.  Alignment with Strategy 2030. The proposed TRTA facility is in line with one of the key 
operational priorities of Strategy 2030 in strengthening governance and institutional capacity as 
the basis for development. It will support public management reforms and financial stability and 
strengthen service delivery and capacity of the member countries in South Asia.  
 
3.  Need for Better Project Implementation. ADB needs to uphold high standards for 
financial management, project management, and procurement and contract management to 
implement  Strategy  2030.  The  outcome  of  the  TRTA  facility  will  be  improved  project 
implementation and portfolio performance in South Asia for faster and higher quality of project 
implementation, timely contract awards and accelerated disbursement of project financing.  
 
4.  The President approved the memo on Strengthening ADB’s Financial Management in 
Sovereign  Operations  on  10  December  2018.  This  initiative  aims  to  provide  targeted  and 
sustained capacity building programs for executing and implementing agencies, and national 
public  and  private  auditors.  In  response  to  the  initiative,  the  TRTA  facility  will  work  with 
government entities that are taking on a larger share of public service delivery to improve their 
financial management capacities. 
 
5.  The TRTA facility will promote the adoption of advanced technology applications to 
improve the quality of project design and project management in response to Strategy 2030. The 
TA  will  cover  pilot  testing  for  the  application  of  advanced  technologies  upon  demand.  A 
preliminary assessment will be conducted for potential areas of project monitoring and reporting, 
use of drone technology, and application of building information modeling (BIM).  
 
6.  The TRTA facility seeks to maintain ADB’s operational efficiency and effectiveness to 
support better project implementation during the reform and rationalization of ADB’s procurement 
system.  It  will  complement  and  reinforce  procurement  related  initiatives  conducted  by  the 
Procurement,  Portfolio  and  Financial  Management  Department  (PPFD)  and  other  regional 
departments.  Drawing  on  lessons  learned  from  these  initiatives,  the  South  Asia  Regional 
 
1  ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance for Improving Procurement in South Asia Department. Manila.

2 
Department (SARD) will continue to develop appropriate actions for longer-term sustainability of 
procurement and institutional capacity development among its member countries.  
 
7.  On project-specific interventions, the TRTA facility will provide support to two energy 
projects in the pipeline namely BAN: Dhaka and Western Zone Transmission Grid Expansion 
Project and IND: Maharashtra Rural High Voltage Distribution (HVD) System Program. Both the 
Government of Bangladesh and the Government of India are considering the application of drones 
in the power transmission and distribution sector where drones can be used for stringing of 
transmission and distribution lines. Under the TRTA facility, consultancy support for use of drones 
can be provided along with procurement and contract management assistance due to the high-
value procurement for works, turnkey and supply and installation contracts for both projects. 
Financial management and reporting support are also required for the executing agency of the 
Maharashtra Rural HVD Program. 
 
8.  The TRTA facility will take a partnership and demand-driven approach that supports 
executing and implementing agencies and other key stakeholders in consultation with respective 
developing member country (DMC) governments. This will ensure ownership by and commitment 
from executing and implementing agencies. 
 
9.  The TRTA facility will complement other TA projects in supporting improved project 
implementation and not duplicate ongoing assistance which addresses portfolio management in 
general.  
 
10.  Since the proposed TRTA facility will cover all South Asian countries, and ultimately all 
sectors within these countries, it would not be appropriate or possible to incorporate the proposed 
TA into a single loan-financed operation. This TRTA facility is not listed in the current Country 
Operations Business Plans (COBPs) but will support projects listed in the COBPs (Appendix 2).2 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
11.  Output  1:  Financial  management  capacity  of  executing/implementing  agencies 
improved. The TRTA facility will support financial management capacity building of government 
agencies  in  the  South  Asia  region.  This  will  include  providing  support  to  executing  and 
implementing agencies and supreme audit institutions to address issues related to Audited Project 
Financial Statements (APFS) and Audited Entity Financial Statements (AEFS) in the timely 
submission and improved quality of these reports. The TRTA facility will support workshops and 
related training programs on financial management. The training programs would be identified 
based on the assessment of capacity of executing agencies. In addition, consultants will be 
engaged  to  review  and  provide  analysis  of  issues  and  proposed  measures  for  financial 
management strengthening. 
 
12.  At least ten training programs will be conducted for staff of executing agencies and 
supreme audit institutions on accounting and financial statements/reports preparation and ADB 
financial reporting and audit requirements. Consulting firms will be engaged to conduct at least

four  studies  on  the  financial  management  capacity  assessment  of  DMCs,  and  high  risk 
executing/implementing agencies and projects. Individual consultants will also be engaged to 
review APFS/AEFS, provide feedback to executing/implementing agencies, and enhance their 
financial management monitoring systems.  
 
13.  Output 2: Project management and evaluation capacity of executing/implementing 
agencies  strengthened  using  innovative  technology  applications.  One  of  the  guiding 
principles for ADB’s operations in Strategy 2030 is promoting innovative technology. ADB will 
proactively seek ways to promote the use of advanced technologies across its operations and 
provide capacity building support to DMCs. The use of advance technology will improve efficiency 
in data collection, monitoring, analysis and evaluation, which will increase efficiency and reduce 
cost as the main drivers for widespread adoption.  
 
14.  The TRTA facility will introduce the use of digital, cloud-based and real-time applications 
to project monitoring and reporting. Digital reporting forms to be filled up on mobile and tablet 
applications can provide day-to-day updates from the field with data stored in the cloud for easy 
retrieval and access from any location. Data collected can be analyzed and presented in different 
formats or dashboards tailored to specific needs or users. This will facilitate  efficient data 
collection, access and analysis for enhanced project implementation monitoring. 
 
15.  The TRTA facility will promote the application of drones in project implementation to DMCs 
who have not yet started using this technology and the dissemination of best practices and 
lessons learned from those who already do. The application of drones offers improved efficiency 
in project management. This is particularly true for the implementation of road projects but also 
for urban projects. For the latter, drones would be useful for laying of pipelines and drains, 
designing waste collection, collecting housing data for urban planning, and developing post 
disaster hazard maps. Drones are also reliable in the evaluation of projects specially during 
project completion as they provide precise data, capture visual imagery, minimize down-time and 
improve safety. 
 
16.  Based on consultations between ADB and relevant agencies in each country, the TRTA 
facility will focus on one or two projects in selected DMCs. The selection will depend on existing 
drone legislation in each country. This advanced technology application will subsequently be 
expanded to other projects. Individual consultants on drone technology will be engaged to assist 
in the data gathering including a drone pilot.  
 
17.  The TRTA facility may also consider the use of building information modeling (BIM) to 
better monitor projects during construction. BIM provides simulation tools that visualize the 
progress of works. The software also includes a program planning and cost component. The 
combination of these project management factors will help anticipate, avoid, minimize or mitigate 
project risks, thereby improving overall coordination, communication and collaboration between 
stakeholders. 
 
18.   The application of these advanced technologies can be done through workshops, training 
sessions, and project management applications. Project agencies will be closely consulted to 
ensure implementation of the proposed outputs. 
 
19.  Workshops and related training programs will focus on critical needs and identified 
problems. Good practices and lessons will be documented, shared, and replicated. Brief study 
tours to locations where advanced technology is effectively implemented will also be considered.

4 
20.  Output 3: Procurement and contract management capacity enhanced. The TRTA 
facility will continue end-to-end support for improving procurement results by providing hands-on 
support and direct assistance during key stages of the procurement process to executing and 
implementing agencies on a demand basis, or whom ADB project teams assess would benefit 
from such support. The procurement operations would include works, equipment, and consulting 
services, among others.  
 
21.  The support would cover as necessary the entire procurement cycle, from preparation of 
procurement documentation to award of contracts. This includes assistance with evaluating the 
results of procurement invitations and obtaining the approval of the outcome of the evaluation. 
More specifically, training programs will include selection of consultants, contract management, 
and project readiness under the 2017 ADB Procurement Policy and Procurement Regulations for 
ADB Borrowers. The objective would be effective and transparent procurement for all ADB-
supported projects across the region.  
 
22.  The TRTA facility would aim to develop a training module on procurement of works, 
contract  management  and  dispute  resolution  based  under  FIDIC  conditions  of  contract  in 
coordination with PPFD. Individual international and national procurement consultants including 
a  FIDIC  expert  will  be  engaged  to  develop  the  module  and  provide  hands-on  support  to 
executing/implementing agencies. 
 
23.  To support the roll out of the 2017 ADB Procurement Policy and Procurement Regulations 
for ADB Borrowers, refresher training courses and sessions will be conducted by individual 
international and national procurement consultants. Knowledge sharing sessions on problems 
encountered  in  procurement  under  ADB-financed  projects  will  also  be  conducted  among 
executing and implementing agencies. Resource persons and ADB staff will participate in the 
training programs and workshops. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
24.  The TRTA facility is estimated to cost $2,500,000 million to be financed on a grant basis 
from ADB’s Technical Assistance Fund (TASF-VI). The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 1. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
25.  The TRTA facility will commence in October 2019 and will be completed by September 
2024. ADB will be the executing agency. SARD’s Portfolio, Results, and Quality Control Unit is 
the  focal  point  within  ADB  and  will  be  responsible  for  the  coordination,  supervision,  and 
implementation of all TA activities. The unit will be responsible for the selection, engagement, and 
evaluation of consultants and will manage and oversee TA implementation, working closely with 
the resident missions within SARD and executing and implementing agencies in South Asia 
DMCs.

27.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions.3 The TRTA facility will be implemented by firms (national, 48 person-
months) and international and national individual consultants (69 person-months for international 
and 130 person-months for national). Additional consultants may be recruited as needed. Given 
the diverse nature of the deliverables, some experts or resource persons for studies, training or 
capacity development will be recruited individually on an as-needed basis or to undertake 
specialized technical work as requested by participating executing and implementing agencies. 
Indicative consultant allocation for projects under the TRTA facility are in Appendix 2. 
 
28.  A midterm review of the TRTA facility will be undertaken after 24 months of implementation 
to assess progress, fine-tune outputs, and, if necessary, adjust key activities and implementation 
arrangements. A full assessment will be undertaken upon TA completion to report on the 
achievements and results, and to share the lessons learned. 
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
29.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,500,000 on a grant basis for 
the Technical Assistance for Improving Project Implementation and Portfolio Performance in 
South Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
